comment: North Africa Air Forces - ALL squadrons/gruppi/groups that operated 1940-1943
description: Comprehensive list of air force units from Luftwaffe, Regia Aeronautica, RAF/Commonwealth, and USAAF that participated in North Africa air operations. Covers all major air battles from Operation Compass through Tunisia Campaign.
validation_sources: Imperial War Museums RAF squadron histories
Christopher Shores 'A History of the Mediterranean Air War'
Comando Supremo Italian Air Force records
WITW Game CSV Database (4,097 air groups - validation source)
battles_covered: Siege of Tobruk air battles (April - December 1941)
Battle of Gazala air operations (May - June 1942)
First Battle of El Alamein air support (July 1942)
Second Battle of El Alamein air supremacy (October - November 1942)
scope_rule: ALL air units (squadrons, gruppi, gruppen, groups) that participated in documented North Africa air operations. Includes fighters, bombers, dive bombers, reconnaissance, transport, and special operations units.
data_quality_note: Research completed 2025-10-26. Luftwaffe: 95%+ confidence (Tessin Band 14 + multiple cross-references). Italian: 75-90% confidence (Comando Supremo + Asisbiz). RAF/Commonwealth: 85%+ confidence (Shores + official squadron histories). USAAF: 85-95% confidence (official USAAF histories). WITW CSV database provides validation cross-reference for unit existence and nomenclature.

battles: Overall air command for North Africa
luftwaffe_units.notes: Staff formed February 24, 1941. Redesignated Fliegerkorps Tunis February 1943.
luftwaffe_units.witw_validation: Not directly modeled in WITW (command entity)

luftwaffe_units.notes: Redesignated from Fliegerführer Afrika February 1943. Commanded Luftwaffe operations until May 1943 evacuation.
Primary German fighter unit in North Africa April 1941-December 1942. Sole fighter unit for 18 months.
Joined I./JG 27 September 1941. Claimed 477 aircraft.
Arrived from Russia late October 1941. Withdrew December 1942.
Entire JG 27 in North Africa by December 1941.
Brief North Africa deployment December 1941, returned May 1942. Claimed 113 kills in North Africa plus 61 over Malta.
Organized escort for Ju-52 transports Tunisia-Sicily early 1943.
Operated from Pantelleria summer 1942 for Malta operations.
Arrived direct from Russian Front October 1942, replacing JG 27. Evacuated May 8, 1943.
Arrived December 1942. Evacuated May 1943.
Last German fighter unit in North Africa. Evacuated May 8-10, 1943.
Staff with Geschwaderkommodore Maj. Müncheberg from October 1942.
Deployed November 1942 with Fw 190s. Claimed 150 kills against 8 combat losses. Returned to France mid-March 1943.
Rushed to North Africa February 1941 to support Afrika Korps. Left January 1942.
Dispatched to Tripoli February 1941. Redesignated III./StG 3 on January 12, 1942.
Staff based in Libya. I./StG 1 and II./StG 2 subordinated early 1941.
Joined II./StG 3 at Fuka by July 1, 1942.
Based at Fuka by July 1, 1942. Supported First El Alamein.
Formed from redesignated II./StG 2 on January 12, 1942. Fought to destruction in theater.
First Luftwaffe unit to North Africa, January 31, 1941. Protected supply routes, reconnaissance, ground support.
Posted to Sicily early 1941. Protected Italy-North Africa supply routes.
Sank three transports from convoy MW 9 February 1941. Led by Hauptmann Joachim Helbig.
Sank Australian destroyer Waterhen July 11, 1941. Participated in Siege of Malta.
Supported Afrika Korps December 1941 to February 1943. Sank multiple convoy vessels March 1943.
Torpedo Geschwader operating He 111s. Attacked Allied shipping from Sicily/Sardinia bases.
Detachment of 3-4 Ju 88 sent to Benghazi mid-January 1941, becoming first Luftwaffe air unit in North Africa.
Desert Rescue Squadron led by Staffelkapitän Heinz Kroseberg. Operated Fieseler Fi 156 Storch. Rescued Axis and Allied airmen.

notes.luftwaffe_scope: 46 total units identified. NO Luftwaffe presence in 1940 (all operations began January-February 1941). JG 27 was dominant fighter unit for 18 months. Tunisia saw peak concentration of units in 1943-Q1. Final evacuation May 8-10, 1943.
notes.luftwaffe_witw_validation: 14 units cross-referenced with WITW _airgroup.csv database (IDs 100-128 for JG units). WITW coverage is Western Front-focused but includes major North Africa units.
notes.full_luftwaffe_list: See research files for complete 46-unit breakdown including reconnaissance, night fighter, ground attack, and special operations units.

regia_aeronautica_units.notes: First MC.202 unit sent to Africa, November 1941. Part of 4° Stormo. Operated until Tunisia evacuation
Part of 4° Stormo. Franco Lucchini's unit. Entire 4° Stormo in Libya by end of November 1941
Part of 1° Stormo. First unit selected for MC.202 equipment. Entire 1° Stormo in Libya by end of November 1941
Part of 1° Stormo. First unit selected for MC.202 equipment. Transferred to North Africa late October 1941
Part of 3° Stormo. Initially operated against Malta before transfer to Libya
Part of 2° Stormo. At time of Tobruk offensive, 2° Stormo had 63 MC.200s (52 serviceable)

regia_aeronautica_units.aircraft_type: Macchi MC.200 Saetta / Fiat CR.42 Falco
regia_aeronautica_units.notes: Operated CR.42 initially, later MC.200. Part of 2° Stormo. Based at Castelbenito June 1940
Autonomous fighter group. Moved to Benghazi January 1942 alongside 6° and 8° Gruppi
Autonomous fighter group. Commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Innocenzo Monti
Commanded by Captain Alessandro Cerutti. Limited information available
Commanded by Major Guido Fea
Commanded by Major Giuseppe Capasso
Commanded by Major Giovanni Masoero
Commanded by Lieutenant Colonel Bruno Cudugnello. Autonomous fighter group

regia_aeronautica_units.aircraft_type: Fiat G.50 Freccia / Fiat CR.42 Falco
regia_aeronautica_units.notes: Commanded by Major Michele Mandara. Mixed equipment
37 G.50s arrived end of January 1941. Included pilot Tullio De Prato
Arrived in Libya July 1941

regia_aeronautica_units.aircraft_type: Fiat CR.42 Falco / Fiat G.50 Freccia
regia_aeronautica_units.notes: Transferred to Libya end of January 1941 after deployment against British Isles from Belgium
Assault/ground attack role. Operating in 1942 order of battle
Part of 53° Stormo. Operating in Libya 1940
Primary bomber wing in Libya at war start. 107 SM.79s total in Libya June 1940
Mixed SM.79 and SM.81 equipment. Part of 5ª Squadra Aerea eastern sector command
Active against Allied shipping in Aegean during Crete invasion, then redeployed to Libya
Active during Crete invasion, then redeployed to Libya for anti-shipping operations
25 Z.1007 aircraft total in North Africa July 1942
Operating Z.1007bis in North Africa 1942
14 BR.20s arrived 27 Feb 1941 from Belgium. Used for convoy escort and bombing Tobruk
Sent to North Africa July 1941-April 1942 for night attacks against British
Land attack wing. Part of 5ª Squadra Aerea western sector command at war start

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Protected allied armour during El Alamein breakout, destroyed Ju 87 Stukas

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 7 Wing SAAF
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Converted to Tomahawk summer 1941, part of No. 7 Wing SAAF (best dive bombing unit by May 1943)

raf_commonwealth_units.aircraft_type: Hawker Hurricane Mk I/II, P-40 Tomahawk/Kittyhawk
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Most substantial service record of any DAF squadron, 217 aerial victories. Originally reconnaissance, converted to fighter 1941
sources: No. 3 Squadron RAAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 7 Wing SAAF
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Transitioned to Egypt from East Africa, part of No. 7 Wing SAAF (best dive bombing unit by May 1943)

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 7 Wing SAAF
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of No. 7 Wing SAAF (best dive bombing unit by May 1943)
Converted to Hurricane IID anti-tank role April 1942 with 40mm Vickers 'S' guns. Previously tactical recon with Lysander/Hurricane escort
sources: No. 6 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Returned from Greece Q2 1941, part of No. 3 (S.A.) Wing for Operation Crusader
Initially in Kenya, served in Italian Somaliland and Ethiopia until June 1941, disbanded. Later reformed as fighter-bomber squadron but not in North Africa theater during this period
First SAAF air attack of WWII on 11 June 1940 against Moyale, Ethiopia. Maryland bomber squadron
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Withdrawn August 1942 to convert to Martin Marauder
Formed from personnel of Squadrons 11, 15, and 16. Maryland and Baltimore bomber
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Operational debut of Boston in Middle East. Successfully bombed Mareth Line. Re-assigned to Army Cooperation before Operation Crusader
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Based Egypt at outbreak, served in Western Desert, Greece, and Crete before Far East deployment
sources: No. 30 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.aircraft_type: Gloster Gladiator, Hawker Hurricane Mk IIc
raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 243 Wing, No. 212 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Returned from Greece Q2 1941. Hurricane IIc by El Alamein
Reinforced Egypt November 1940, supported Operation Compass. Continued operations through Tunisia
Reinforced Egypt November 1940, supported Operation Compass with Wellington bombers
Wellington IC Nov 1940-May 1942, Wellington III May 1942-July 1943, Wellington X May 1943+
sources: No. 40 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Reformed as fighter squadron 1 January 1942 after returning from Ethiopia. Mixed Hurricane I/Tomahawk. Reconnaissance role at El Adem
sources: No. 40 Squadron SAAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of No. 253 Wing for Operation Battleaxe June 1941. Operated throughout Middle East campaigns
sources: No. 45 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Converted to Blenheim March 1939. Baltimore I/II/III May 1942-March 1943, Baltimore IIIA March-Oct 1943, Baltimore IV June 1943-May 1944
sources: No. 55 Squadron RAF History of War
Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Converted to Wellington 18 September 1940. Involved in Iraq and Syria 1941, then North Africa campaign
sources: No. 70 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 244 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Hurricanes shipped via Takoradi to Egypt, entire Western Desert and Tunisia campaign
sources: No. 73 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.aircraft_type: Gloster Gladiator, Hawker Hurricane Mk IIc
raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 243 Wing, No. 212 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Sent to Greece, returned via Cyprus/Syria. First hurri-bombers in Operation Crusader

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 244 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Posted Egypt Feb 1942, personnel April, Spitfires August. Palm Sunday Massacre 18 April 1943 (75 Axis aircraft destroyed)
sources: No. 92 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: SAAF squadron operating Hurricanes in Desert Air Force
Reformed 1 April 1941. October 1941 detachment to Malta, then moved to Egypt. Night bomber operations
sources: No. 104 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Reformed Kabrit Egypt 1 August 1941. Night bomber, attacked Axis ports in Libya and Greece. Liberators Nov 1941-June 1942 for Balkans supply drops
sources: No. 108 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.aircraft_type: Gloster Gladiator, Curtiss Tomahawk, Curtiss Kittyhawk IA
raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 239 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. First to use Tomahawk July 1941. 'Shark Squadron' - first to use shark mouth logo. Kittyhawk Dec 1941+. Clive Caldwell commanded 1942
Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Returned from Greece Q2 1941. Part of No. 3 (S.A.) Wing for Operation Crusader
Received Hurricanes February 1942, operated in Palestine and North Africa for two years
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 244 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Departed Middle East Feb 1942, arrived Egypt April. First Spitfire squadron in Western Desert. First Spitfire victory in Western Desert 8 June 1942
sources: No. 145 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Reformed December 1940 Malta. Recalled from Malta March 1941 (user provided). Attacked Axis bases Italy/Libya. Moved back to Malta Dec 1942, disbanded
Operation Torch November 1942. First use of Spitfire as fighter bomber in North Africa (March 1943 'Rhubarb' sorties Souk el Khemis, Tunisia)
Moved to Gibraltar and Algeria November 1942 for Operation Torch
Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Lysander Jan 1939-May 1942, Hurricane Nov 1940-Sept 1942. Hurricanes took over most recon, Lysanders artillery support/close recon
Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Part of No. 253 Wing for Operation Battleaxe

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 243 Wing, No. 212 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Converted to Hurricane January 1939, flew throughout war in Middle East/North Africa
Part of Collishaw's force June 1940. Bombays used for night bombing until end 1940, then purely transport (Greece evacuation, Tobruk supply)
sources: No. 216 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Returned to operational light bomber duties May 1942 with Baltimore, supporting Eighth Army. Later became 30 Squadron SAAF
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Re-equipped Hurricanes March 1940. Left for Middle East May 1941 via Malta to Egypt
Formed from No. 1 Squadron Southern Rhodesia AF April 1940. East Africa campaign 1940. Moved Egypt May 1941, re-equipped Hurricane for tactical recon Western Desert. Iraq May 1942, Libya 1942

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 243 Wing, No. 212 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Twenty-eight Hurricanes flew off HMS Victorious June 1941 to Middle East

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 239 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Reformed from K Flight at Aqir 1 April 1941. Tomahawks April-Feb 1942, then Kittyhawk fighter bomber
sources: No. 250 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 233 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Arrived Egypt with Hurricanes end November 1940, ready for Operation Compass. Operated Hurricanes at Gerawla April 1941. Kittyhawk by El Alamein
Beaufighter I April 1941-June 1942, Beaufighter VI Nov 1942-Feb 1944. Egypt/Libya May 1941-Nov 1942. Long range escort, ground attack, intruder missions. Malta Nov 1942-June 1943
sources: No. 272 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Arrived Egypt with Hurricanes end November 1940, ready for Operation Compass. Operated Hurricanes at Gerawla April 1941. Renamed No. 462 Squadron RAAF early 1943

Formed 10 October 1941 Aqir Palestine (exile unit). Hurricane I Oct 1941-Sept 1942, Hurricane IIB Aug 1942-Oct 1943. Desert Jan-June 1942, returned Sept. Strafed Italian XX Corps HQ 28 Oct 1942 (anniversary of Greek invasion). Shipping protection Libya 1943
sources: No. 335 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: ONLY Canadian squadron in Desert Air Force. Formed England 27 Nov 1941, sent Egypt April 1942. 5 months Suez/Nile defense. First victory 26 Sept 1942 (Ju.88). April 1943 only Canadian squadron in DAF, close support Eighth Army Tunisia. 'Windsor Spitfires'
Commenced operations February 1942 with Kittyhawk. 15 months North Africa/Tunisia fighter and fighter-bomber roles. 49 Axis aircraft destroyed. Nickname 'Desert Harassers' from Lord Haw Haw
Flew Hurricanes with Desert Air Force
Early 1943 No. 274 Squadron RAF renamed No. 462 Squadron RAAF despite mainly British personnel

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, No. 244 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Converted to Spitfire March 1942, departed Middle East April, reached Egypt June. Fighter sweeps Western Desert late June. El Alamein, then westwards to Tunisia
sources: No. 601 Squadron RAF History of War

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 57th Fighter Group, No. 233 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 57th Fighter Group. Launched from USS Ranger July 1942, flew across Africa to Palestine. Attached to RAF/SAAF/RAAF squadrons for training. Official operations October 1942
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 57th Fighter Group, No. 233 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 57th Fighter Group. Launched from USS Ranger July 1942, flew across Africa to Palestine. Official operations October 1942
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 57th Fighter Group, No. 239 Wing, No. 211 Group
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 57th Fighter Group. Launched from USS Ranger July 1942, flew across Africa to Palestine. Official operations October 1942. Assigned to No. 239 Wing
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 12th Bombardment Group, No. 232 Wing
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 12th Bombardment Group. Arrived Egypt July 1942, first mission 31 August 1942. Supported El Alamein, Operation Torch. Reinforced 310th BG Algeria Feb 1943
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 12th Bombardment Group, No. 232 Wing
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 12th Bombardment Group. Arrived Egypt July 1942, first mission 31 August 1942. Supported El Alamein, Operation Torch. Reinforced 310th BG Algeria Feb 1943
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 12th Bombardment Group, No. 232 Wing
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 12th Bombardment Group. Arrived Egypt July 1942, first mission 31 August 1942. Supported El Alamein. Helped break up Mareth Line attack. Remained in Egypt while 81st/82nd to Algeria
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force, 12th Bombardment Group, No. 232 Wing
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Part of 12th Bombardment Group. Arrived Egypt July 1942, first mission 31 August 1942. Supported El Alamein. Helped break up Mareth Line attack. Remained in Egypt while 81st/82nd to Algeria
sources: Desert Air Force Order of Battle El Alamein

raf_commonwealth_units.designation: Groupe de Chasse II/5 La Fayette
raf_commonwealth_units.parent_formation: Desert Air Force/Free French Air Forces
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: After Operation Torch (9 Nov 1942), Army of Africa joined Free France. Re-equipped with P-40F Warhawk 25 November 1942. Official transfer ceremony 9 January 1943 Casablanca (12 ex-USAAC P-40F)
sources: Escadron de Chasse 2/4 La Fayette Wikipedia

raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Photographic Reconnaissance squadron assigned from Northwest African PR Wing to Desert Air Force for later North Africa campaign

raf_commonwealth_units.aircraft_type: Martin Maryland I, Martin Baltimore I/II/IIIA/V
raf_commonwealth_units.notes: Reconnaissance and bomber duties Middle East 1942-1943. Maryland I, Baltimore I/II Feb-Nov 1942, Baltimore I/II/IIIA/V Aug 1942-Nov 1943. Western Egypt/Libya bases
sources: No. 203 Squadron RAF History of War

usaaf_units.notes: First USAAF fighter group in North Africa. Moved to Middle East July-Aug 1942, began operations October 1942. 72 P-40s launched from USS Ranger. Transferred to 12th AF control Feb 1943
Moved to Middle East Oct-Nov 1942. Became operational mid-Feb 1943 from Causeway airfield after training with 57th FG. Transferred to 12th AF control Feb 1943
Moved to Middle East Oct-Dec 1942. Group HQ remained in Egypt while squadrons worked with other groups in Tunisia. Transferred to 12th AF control Feb 1943
Allocated to Twelfth AF for Operation Torch. Ground echelon landed at Arzeu D-Day (8 Nov 1942). Operated from Algeria. Aircraft taken to reinforce 14th FG
First P-38 operations 11 Nov 1942 from Youks-les-Bains. Lost 32 of 54 pilots and reduced to 7 aircraft by 28 Jan 1943. Withdrawn from North Africa 28 Jan 1943
Transferred from Britain to replace 14th FG on 28 Jan 1943. Kept in Britain as reserve during Operation Torch
76 P-40Fs transported aboard USS Chenango. Catapult-launched for Operation Torch 8 Nov 1942. Landed at Port Lyautey airdrome. Ground attack and close support missions
RAF convinced USAAF to use Spitfires instead of P-39s. Flew Spitfires from Gibraltar to Algeria 8 Nov 1942. First Eighth AF fighter group operational (Aug 1942). Claimed 61 victories by May 13, 1943
Equipped with Spitfire Mk. Vs instead of P-39s. Flew from Gibraltar to Algeria 8 Nov 1942 (6 aircraft ran out of fuel). Claimed 86 victories by May 13, 1943

75 P-39Ls and P-39-400s flew from England to Port Lyautey, Morocco Jan-Feb 1943. Ground attack, patrol, interception, convoy protection, reconnaissance. Defended Algerian coast. Less than 20 total kills
First USAAF raid on German forces in Tunisia 16 Nov 1942 (6 B-17s attacked Sidi Ahmed airfield, Bizerte). Moved from England to Algeria Nov 1942. Part of 5th Bombardment Wing
Deployed from Sioux City AAB, Iowa 22 Feb 1943. Began operations from Navarin Airfield, Algeria 22 Feb 1943. Joined 97th and 301st BGs. Part of 5th Bombardment Wing
Flown from England to Algeria Nov 1942 after Operation Torch. Operated from St-Donat, Algeria (6 Mar 1943) and Oudna, Tunisia (6 Aug 1943). Part of 5th Bombardment Wing
Arrived Navarin, Algeria 22 Apr 1943. First mission 28 Apr 1943 to Terranova, Sardinia. Moved to Massicault, Tunisia 31 Jul 1943. Flew 25 missions from Chateau D'un, Algeria
First operation 2 Dec 1942 against Gabes, Tunisia. Attacked harbors and shipping Dec 1942-May 1943. Based at Dar el Koudia (Jun 1943) and Menzel Temime, Tunisia (Aug 1943)
Two squadrons with 12th AF moving east across North Africa, others with 9th AF bombing Mareth Line. Distinguished Unit Citation Oct 1942-Aug 1943
First B-25 Mitchell group (Aug-Sep 1941). Doolittle Raid participant. Converted to B-26 summer 1942. Combat debut 30 Dec 1942 from Telergma, Algeria attacking Gabes airfield
Maximum 13 operational aircraft with 310th BG Nov-Dec 1942. Successful low-level attack on Sousse harbor 14 Dec 1942. Moved to Djedeida, Tunisia 26 Jun 1943
Began combat Apr 1943. Focused on Axis shipping Sicily-Tunisia supply route Apr-Jul 1943. Based at Massicault, Tunisia (29 Jun 1943) and El Bathan, Tunisia (28 Jul 1943)
Moved to Mediterranean Jan-Mar 1943. Entered combat second half of March 1943. Maritime interdiction. Based at Souk-el-Arba, Tunisia (Jun 1943) and Soliman, Tunisia (Aug 1943)
Activated 20 Aug 1942. Reached North Africa Mar 1943, joined 9th AF. Began operations Apr 1943. DUC for Apr-Aug 1943 supporting Eighth Army. Transferred to 12th AF Aug 1943
First USAAF A-20 group in large-scale combat. Landed Morocco Nov 1942. Low-level missions Dec 1942-May 1943. DUC for Kasserine Pass (11 attacks 22 Feb, 1 loss). Record sorties 6 May 1943
Remanned and equipped with A-20s, moved to North Africa, then converted to A-36 aircraft. Began operations with 12th AF Jun 1943
